image.altText: Two men at press conferences wear suits and stand outside.

props.synopsis: Crossbenchers who could decide the fate of Tasmania's minority government have give mixed responses to new commitments by the Liberals and Labor.

title.children: Tasmania's major parties try to adapt as crossbenchers wield influence

image.altText: Logged trees in a pile in a forest.

props.synopsis: The Tasmanian Greens welcome a Liberal decision to back out of a plan to open up more native forests for logging, but some opponents say it is a bid to woo crossbench support ahead of an imminent no-confidence motion.

title.children: Liberals walk back plan to open 39,000ha of native forest to logging

image.altText: Andrea Dawkins with greyhound

props.synopsis: As the RSPCA celebrates the Tasmanian government's decision to end greyhound racing by 2029 and prepares to rehome hundreds of dogs, one industry stalwart says he is "devastated" by the move.

title.children: RSPCA 'overwhelmed with joy and hope' at end of Tasmanian greyhound racing

image.altText: A lady sitting and smiling off camera.

props.synopsis: Tasmanian Labor will appoint independent upper house member Ruth Forrest as treasurer — if the party is able to form minority government when parliament resumes.

title.children: Labor names independent MLC as would-be treasurer in bid for government

image.altText: a woman and a man standing on a street on a sunny day

props.synopsis: Premier Rockliff's recent move to appoint an independent to the prominent position has been hailed by some as a show of collaboration across the chamber, but others question whether it's a move to neutralise a potentially opposing voice during a time of political turmoil.

title.children: Independent MLC appointed as Leader for the Government in Tasmania's upper house

image.altText: Three children sitting on a mat, playing with colourful lego.

props.synopsis: For many Australian parents the 9am to 3pm school day doesn't line up with their working day, but in large parts of the country accessing a spot at before and after-school care is not an option.

title.children: These are Australia's best and worst regions to access out-of-school care

image.altText: A small bright green airplane in a hanger.

props.synopsis: It's been a week since Tasmanian couple Gregory Vaughan and Kim Worner along with their dog Molly, stepped into a small green plane and flew away without a trace.

title.children: How can a plane go missing in 2025? Tasmanian couple's disappearance sparks questions

image.altText: A satellite view of a city block in Hobart showing a large building and car park.

props.synopsis: Community advocates want a massive CBD block turned into medium-density housing rather than "another car yard for Hobart", with UTAS putting the site on the market.

title.children: YIMBYS want this massive CBD block turned into dense housing

image.altText: A woman, looking on, with art visible on a wall behind her.

props.synopsis: Russia's relentless drone and missile attacks on Ukraine mean the arrival of long-awaited US-made patriot air defence systems cannot come soon enough.

title.children: 'War of technology' given boost as Patriot air defences head to Ukraine

image.altText: A Palestinian woman in a black headdress making a peace symbol with her right hand standing in front of mounds of rubble

props.synopsis: Starving Palestinians in Gaza say they have no other option than to resort to direct online fundraising campaigns and capitalising on social media trends to feed their families.

title.children: A 'dystopian Darwinist experiment' in Gaza forces Palestinians to crowdfund

props.synopsis: Despite two poor seasons, climate-change worries and growing competition from Japan and New Zealand, Australian alpine businesses are making substantial investments that signal a firm belief in the future of our winter wonderlands.

title.children: Mega-investment signals fierce belief in Australia's snow business

image.altText: A close up image of Tony Burke in a suit and tie.

props.synopsis: The home affairs minister says there is "precedent" for Australia to recognise countries occupied by terrorist forces, even as the federal government maintains Hamas can play no role in a future Palestinian state.

title.children: There is 'precedent' to recognise countries under terrorist occupation: Burke

image.altText: Jim Shen stands at the edge of the indoor pool with a pink towel around his neck.

props.synopsis: Heating Australia's beloved aquatic centres comes at a cost to the environment. With centres accounting for more than 50 per cent of some councils' annual emissions, it's putting local government net-zero targets at risk.

title.children: Heated public pools threaten Victorian councils' net-zero targets

image.altText: An icebreaker makes it way through Antarctic waters.

props.synopsis: Lead the research and lead the way on Antarctica but as the US cuts environmental funding questions are raised about the future of science there.

title.children: Why China may soon be seen as the new authority on Antarctica

image.altText: Tim David raises his bat in celebration of his half-century

props.synopsis: Tim David came to the crease with Australia in dire straits before unleashing on South Africa's attack in the first T20 in Darwin.

title.children: David's brilliance and Maxwell's acrobatics help Australia down South Africa in first T20

image.altText: Small group of people standing at rear of police vehicle in security vision.

props.synopsis: A man has been airlifted to hospital with gunshot wounds to his chest and his brother arrested on charges of shooting with intent to murder.

title.children: Man charged with shooting his brother at rural property in NSW

image.altText: Two AFL footballers high five wearing Adelaide Crows guernseys

props.synopsis: West Coast put in one of its best performances of a forgettable season against the AFL's ladder leaders, Adelaide, but it wasn't quite enough to secure a fairytale upset win at Perth Stadium.

title.children: Thilthorpe recovers from scary bump as Crows avoid biggest upset in 20 years

image.altText: Mitchell Moses yells in celebration of a field goal

props.synopsis: Mitchell Moses's clutch kicking proves the difference once again for the Eels, with the halfback slotting a 75th-minute field goal to get them over the line in a 19-18 win against the Cowboys in Parramatta.

title.children: NQ coach says bunker right to overturn game-winner after 'cheeky' Moses dive

image.altText: Members of an orchestra on stage.

props.synopsis: The Australian Chamber Orchestra's Richard Tognetti has warned that the ANU's plan to axe its School of Music would result in an "act of cultural vandalism", with another Canberra ensemble saying its offer to help has been rejected.

title.children: Australian Chamber Orchestra slams ANU plan as 'cultural vandalism'

image.altText: A woman holds a baby while smiling and standing by the river

props.synopsis: They talk of sleepless nights, a "love like no other", maybe even the odd meltdown. But not of the silent fury you might feel towards the demands of motherhood. Experts say maternal anger isn't just a normal response to impossible expectations: It's a vital sign about what mothers need — and aren't getting.

title.children: How mums are 'gaslit' into feeling guilt instead of 'completely normal' anger

image.altText: A composite image of different packages of food cropped in to show the weight and e-mark.

props.synopsis: Here’s what you need to know about the Average Quantity System and how it may be impacting your grocery shop.

title.children: What the e symbol after the weight on some packaged foods means

image.altText: Daniel Hoogstra looks seriously at the camera.

props.synopsis: Western United fans have expressed their disappointment and sadness after the team was stripped of its A-League licence late last week.

title.children: Western United fans 'disappointed' after A-League licence withdrawal

image.altText: Brisban inner subrub house rooftops

props.synopsis: When the RBA cuts rates, it drives property prices higher. What does it mean for housing affordability?

title.children: The RBA is tipped to cut rates but borrowers might have to wait longer

image.altText: Red and white boxing gloves on the floor of a ring.

props.synopsis: Japanese boxers Shigetoshi Kotari and Hiromasa Urakawa died days after suffering brain injuries in separate fights on the same card at Tokyo's Korakuen Hall.

title.children: Two Japanese boxers on same card die from brain injuries

image.altText: A publicity still from the 1975 film Picnic at Hanging Rock.

props.synopsis: Australia’s national identity rests on silences and erasures. Like the missing schoolgirls, the colonial subject is lost, unsure of who belongs and whose history matters.

title.children: Picnic at Hanging Rock is just as unsettling and relevant 50 years on

image.altText: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy speaks during a press briefing raising his hands

props.synopsis: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says a meeting with European and US officials to discuss the ongoing war with Russia was constructive.

title.children: Zelenskyy calls for 'lasting peace' after officials meet in UK

image.altText: A graphic showing a woman and a young girl and DNA strands.

props.synopsis: Shandee Blackburn was murdered in 2013. Twelve years later, the fallout of botched forensic work has led to a reckoning for Queensland's forensic lab.

title.children: How the murder of a 23yo woman uncovered a 'forensic train wreck'

image.altText: Young girl standing outside, smiling, wearing pink Dora The Explorer bucket hat.

props.synopsis: A campaign to educate people about the dangers of coercive control and cults begins in southern Queensland following the death of an eight-year-old girl.

title.children: Child's death drives churches to call out cult-like behaviour

image.altText: three police officers detain an elderly woman who was protesting in london

props.synopsis: The Met Police said the 466 arrests for supporting a proscribed organisation were the most made on a single day in the past decade.

title.children: Why UK police arrested 466 people for backing a banned pro-Palestine group

image.altText: A black and white photograph of a man standing by a tree

props.synopsis: From taunting police, escaping prison and commanding political pressure for an early release, charm and intelligence was the secret to Queensland's "elite" bushranger.

title.children: The Wild Scotchman was Queensland's charming, intellectual bushranger

image.altText: bald man with square glasses, black suit jacket, white shirt, red tie holds paper. screen behind says sole financial advisor

props.synopsis: Chinese tech financier and banker Bao Fan has been released by Chinese authorities after vanishing from public view more than two years ago while "cooperating" with an investigation, a former colleague told AFP.

title.children: Chinese tech financier Bao Fan released after probe, says former colleague

image.altText: A graphic showing a man looking at censored images on a phone with the Telegraph and MaskPark logos.

props.synopsis: Women in China urge Beijing to act after exploitative videos and photos, many taken in secret, are shared on Telegram channels.

title.children: Hidden cameras capture explicit videos of women in China

image.altText: A screenshot of an example of Instagram's Map feature in use.

props.synopsis: The social media platform's new feature is something you have to actively opt into. So, if you haven't turned it on, it shouldn't be sharing your location.

title.children: Instagram has a new location-sharing feature. But you have to turn it on yourself

image.altText: A man in a khaki shirt with a camera on his neck holds up an orange lizard in both hands towards camera.

props.synopsis: There is growing momentum in Australia's conservation planning to incorporate First Nations knowledge into the management of culturally significant species such as the great desert skink.

title.children: This lizard faces extinction, but an Indigenous-led plan could save it

image.altText: An Adelaide Crows AFLW player attempts to mark in front of a Collingwood opponent.

props.synopsis: AFLW arrived like a freight train in 2017, changing Australian rules football forever. Photographs have told its story and challenged the status quo.

title.children: AFLW is celebrating 10 seasons, these photographs tell its story
